Section 6 lays down University open to All Classes and Creeds- No person shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence, language, political opinion or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the University or membership of any of the authorities or bodies of the University or admission to any degree or companyrse of study in the University. In making appointments to posts in any service, class or category under the University, the University shall mutatis mutandis, observe the provisions of clauses  a ,  b   c  of rule 14 and the provisions of rules 15, 16 and 17 of the Kerala State and Subordinate Service Rules as demanded from time to time.

concepts.interpretation: Meant to eliminate unjustifiable discrimination; sub-s (1) against individual discrimination, sub-s (2) ensures equality between groups via reservations and rotation rules for backward classes.

concepts.unlisted_description: Mandates non-discrimination and application of reservation/rotation rules to University appointments.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14, mentioned in Section 6 2  lays down a rule of rotation in making appointments. concepts.interpretation: Lays down rotation scheme for reservations in every 20 posts: 10 open merit, 8 OBC, 2 SC/ST; applied in order of vacancy occurrence.

issues.text: What is the correct interpretation of Rules 14 to 17 and their impact on the principle of rotation as applied to service, class or category under the University?

anchor.surface_text: The whole case, therefore, hinged round an interpretation of Rules 14 to 17 and their impact on the principle of rotation as applied to service, class or category under the University.

issues.text: Does the power to apply the rules mutatis mutandis under Section 6(2) include the power to amend substantial provisions of the rules or exempt categories?

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was right in holding that the power to apply the rules mutatis-mutandis does number include the power of amending the substantial provision in the rules.

issues.text: Must the rotation rule under Rule 14(c) be applied to vacancies in the order in which they occur?

anchor.surface_text: Clause  c  of Rule 14 lays down a scheme of rotation for every block of 20 vacancies. But, it does number specifically say that the rule of rotation will be applied in the order in which vacancies occur.

issues.text: Does the University have the power to classify posts into service, class or category reasonably for application of the reservation and rotation rules?

anchor.surface_text: Inasmuch as every statutory power has to be exercised reasonably, we can say that the classification has to be reasonable. Thus the University may treat all the teaching posts as belonging to one class

holdings.text: Section 6(2) lays down the mandatory duty upon the University to observe clauses (a), (b) and (c) of Rule 14, as well as Rules 15, 16 and 17 to every service, class or category under the University.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 2  laws down the mandatory duty upon the University to observe clauses  a ,  b  and  c  of Rule 14, as well as Rules 15, 16 and 17 of the rales set out above. But, it does number indicate the, manner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Section 6(2) imposes mandatory duty without exemption; High Court rightly held Syndicate cannot alter it.

holdings.text: The power to apply the rules mutatis mutandis does not include the power of amending the substantial provisions in the rules or exempting categories.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was right in holding that the power to apply the rules mutatis-mutandis does number include the power of amending the substantial provision in the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutatis mutandis allows only formal inconsequential adaptations for University context, not substantive changes; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: The rotation rule under Rule 14(c) must be applied to vacancies in the order in which they occur, by necessary implication.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  c  of Rule 14 lays down a scheme of rotation for every block of 20 vacancies. But, it does number specifically say that the rule of rotation will be applied in the order in which vacancies occur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary implication from rule's purpose to introduce fixity and prevent abuse; not based on advertisement dates which are fortuitous.

holdings.text: The University has power to reasonably classify posts into service, class or category for application of reservation and rotation rules.
